A **lance** is a type of [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a one-handed weapon that is designed for use in [mounted](/wiki/Mount "Mount") combat, and is made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron").

Lances behave similarly to [polearms](/wiki/Polearm "Polearm"), only dealing full damage when used for [pounding](/wiki/Pounding "Pounding") monsters as well as mounted [melee](/wiki/Melee "Melee") attacks.

## Generation

Lances make up about 0.4% of randomly generated weapons (on the floor, as [death drops](/wiki/Death_drop "Death drop"), or in [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop")).

All [Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight") start with a [+1](/wiki/Enchantment "Enchantment") lance.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[Watchmen](/wiki/Watchmen "Watchmen") and [soldiers](/wiki/Soldier "Soldier") may [be generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a lance.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit da859c5e](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/da859c5eb88e17d04ec2bb37e2c12842e9f4c4a9), lances no longer generate on watchmen and soldiers.

## Lance skill

| Lance   |                                                                             |
| ------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Max     | [Role](/wiki/Role "Role")                                                   |
| Basic   | - [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest"), [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist")       |
| Skilled | * [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai"), [Valkyrie](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie") |
| Expert  | - [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight")                                           |

The lance is the only weapon to use the **lance [skill](/wiki/Skill "Skill")**, and there are no [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") lances.

The range at which a character or monster can [pound](/wiki/Pound "Pound") with a lance varies with skill level - see that article for more information.

## Jousting

When a mounted character attacks an adjacent monster in melee with a lance, there is a skill-dependent chance of **jousting** the monster:[\[4\]](#cite_note-4). the base chance is 1⁄5, and increases by an additional 1⁄5 for each skill level (i.e. 2⁄5 at Basic, 3⁄5 at Skilled, and 4⁄5 at Expert). If jousting as part of [twoweaponing](/wiki/Twoweapon "Twoweapon"), the skill level used is the lower between the character's lance skill and their twoweapon skill, e.g. the chance of jousting with an offhand lance is 1⁄5 if the character is unskilled in two-weapon combat.

A monster that is jousted monster takes +2d10 damage (or +2d2 if the lance is twoweaponed in the offhand), loses all its movement points for that turn, and becomes [stunned](/wiki/Stun "Stun"); the monster is also pushed back one [square](/wiki/Square "Square") in the direction of the melee attack, if they are not currently immobilized (e.g. they are trapped, as opposed to being [sessile](/wiki/Sessile "Sessile")) and are of medium [size](/wiki/Size "Size") or smaller, and the target square is not occupied or deadly. Each joust also has a [luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck")-based chance of breaking the lance (with a hypothetical artifact lance resisting this chance completely), unless the jousting occurs against an [unsolid](/wiki/Unsolid "Unsolid") monster:[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

| Luck | Break chance |
| ---- | ------------ |
| −13  | 1 in 18      |
| −5   | 1 in 43      |
| −1   | 1 in 126     |
| 0    | 1 in 250     |
| +1   | 1 in 9550    |
| +5   | 1 in 10500   |
| +13  | 1 in 12500   |

## Strategy

The lance is an extremely heavy weapon that is only second in [weight](/wiki/Weight "Weight") to the [heavy iron ball](/wiki/Heavy_iron_ball "Heavy iron ball"), and as its base damage is quite low for that weight, a character seeking a weapon solely for pounding will prefer any polearm - the lance's primary perks lie in its jousting ability, which more than makes up for the lance's base damage and turns it into one of the most powerful non-artifact weapons.

Jousts can push monsters into pounding range, and with sufficient player skill it is possible to stay a knight's jump away from monsters with ranged attacks and pound at them without fear of retaliation. Lances are difficult to come by, meaning that most players only attempt this with Knights and their starting lance once they secure enough positive luck - until then, a lance is most safely applied at range, ideally with a backup weapon and/or space to retreat when opponents close in; even low-skill Knights in an open space can make particularly good use of this strategy with their role's [jumping](/wiki/Jumping "Jumping") ability.

[Barracks](/wiki/Barracks "Barracks") offer the best odds of finding a backup lance, particularly in the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") and [Fort Ludios](/wiki/Fort_Ludios "Fort Ludios"), and dedicated lancers can [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish") up a spare or backup if all else fails - a [light source](/wiki/Light_source "Light source") is also worth carrying around to keep the character's pounding range illuminated. A deadly jousting tactic at high skill level is to pound at a monster that comes in range until it moves adjacent to the character, then melee with the lance to push it back into pounding range: this potentially stunlocks monsters to death without them getting a chance to attack, and with enough movement speed even covetous monsters like many of the [demon lords and princes](/wiki/Demon_lords_and_princes "Demon lords and princes") are unlikely to get a single turn in.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

The removal of lances from watchmen and soldier starting inventories means that lances will be much more difficult to come by through regular means for most characters.

## History

The lance first appears in [NetHack 1.3d](/wiki/NetHack_1.3d "NetHack 1.3d").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Lance](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lance "wikipedia:Lance")***

A lance is a long thrusting spear designed to be used by a mounted warrior or cavalry soldier (called a lancer). In ancient and medieval warfare, it evolved into the leading weapon in cavalry charges, and was unsuited for throwing or for repeated thrusting unlike similar weapons typically used by infantry. Lances were often equipped with a vamplate, a small circular plate to prevent the hand sliding up the shaft upon impact; beginning in the late 14th century, they were used in conjunction with a lance rest attached to the breastplate.

Though best known as a military and sporting weapon carried by European knights and men-at-arms, the use of lances was widespread throughout Eastern Asia, the Middle East, and Northern Africa wherever suitable mounts were available. Lancers of the medieval period also carried secondary weapons such as swords, battle axes, war hammers, maces and daggers for use in hand-to-hand combat, since the lance was often a one-use-per-engagement weapon; assuming the lance survived the initial impact without breaking, it was often too long, heavy, and/or slow to be effective in a melee.

## Variants

Some variants add artifact lances, which will not break when jousting as explained above.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the range of pounding is also unrestricted, and lances can hit any square that is two squares away from the wielder.

Two of the five roles that are new to SLASH'EM can raise their skill in lances:

| Polearms |                                         |
| -------- | --------------------------------------- |
| Max      | Role                                    |
| Basic    | - [Ice Mage](/wiki/Ice_Mage "Ice Mage") |
| Skilled  | * [Yeoman](/wiki/Yeoman "Yeoman")       |

### SporkHack

[SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack") changes the additional jousting damage from 2d10 to 2d(5 + XL⁄3).

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), the lance's weight is reduced to 80 aum, and both variants add the [elven lance](/index.php?title=Elven_lance\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Elven lance (page does not exist)"), [droven lance](/wiki/Droven_lance "Droven lance"), [white vibrospear](/index.php?title=White_vibrospear\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "White vibrospear (page does not exist)"), [gold-bladed vibrospear](/index.php?title=Gold-bladed_vibrospear\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Gold-bladed vibrospear (page does not exist)"), and [force pike](/index.php?title=Force_pike\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Force pike (page does not exist)") as weapons that use the lance skill.

[Berith](/wiki/Berith "Berith") is a [spirit](/wiki/Spirits_\(dNetHack\) "Spirits (dNetHack)") that grants skill in lances while bound.

[Iron golems](/wiki/Iron_golem "Iron golem") may be generated with a lance.

There are several artifact lances:

- [Dragonlance](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Dragonlance "DNetHack artifacts") is an unaligned artifact that is made of [dragontooth](/wiki/Dragontooth "Dragontooth"). It has +1d10 [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") and deals +1d20 bonus damage against dragons and reptilians, with a 1⁄10 chance of [canceling](/wiki/Canceling "Canceling") those monsters on hit, subject to their [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)"). While wielded, Dragonlance confers [warning of dragons and reptilians](/wiki/Warned_of_monster_type "Warned of monster type"), and grants vanilla-strength [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection").
- [Rhongomyniad](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Rhongomyniad "DNetHack artifacts") is a lawful artifact that favors Knights and is the first [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift") for Knights. It has +1d3 to-hit and double damage versus all monsters, and if gifted to a character, it unrestricts the riding, [martial arts](/wiki/Martial_arts "Martial arts") and lance skills and comes with a [saddle](/wiki/Saddle "Saddle").
- [The Lance of Uriel](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Lance_of_Uriel "DNetHack artifacts") is a lawful intelligent artifact that is large and made of [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver"). It has +1d7 to-hit and +1d10 damage versus all monsters, and while wielded it grants [automatic searching](/wiki/Automatic_searching "Automatic searching") and [blindness resistance](/wiki/Blindness_resistance "Blindness resistance"), and acts as a [light source](/wiki/Light_source "Light source"); targets that it strikes may be [blinded](/wiki/Blind "Blind"), [gremlins](/wiki/Gremlin "Gremlin") are reduced to dust, and [trolls](/wiki/Troll_\(monster_class\) "Troll (monster class)") are [petrified](/wiki/Petrified "Petrified").
- [The Rod of Lordly Might](/wiki/The_Rod_of_Lordly_Might "The Rod of Lordly Might"), [The Rod of the Elvish Lords](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#The_Rod_of_the_Elvish_Lords "DNetHack artifacts") and [The Sceptre of Lolth](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#The_Sceptre_of_Lolth "DNetHack artifacts") can be [invoked](/wiki/Invoke "Invoke") to take on the form of an appropriate lance.

### FIQHack

In [FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack"), [Dragonbane](/wiki/Dragonbane "Dragonbane") has its [base item](/wiki/Base_item "Base item") changed from a [broadsword](/wiki/Broadsword "Broadsword") to a lance. Dragonbane is the first sacrifice gift for Knights, and deals +1d20 against [dragons](/wiki/Dragon "Dragon") - it also confers reflection while wielded, as in *NetHack*. Dragonbane has half the weight of a regular lance at 90 aum, and being gifted Dragonbane unrestricts riding and provides a free saddle.

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), [Bradamante's Fury](/index.php?title=Bradamante%27s_Fury\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Bradamante's Fury (page does not exist)") is a neutral artifact lance that has +1d5 to-hit and +1d10 damage bonuses versus all monsters. It has a 1⁄10 chance of stunning a monster on each hit, and instantly dismounts any mounted monsters it hits and stuns them.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), a lance can be created at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") by combining a [glaive](/wiki/Glaive "Glaive") and a [javelin](/wiki/Javelin "Javelin").

The ability to forge lances of a desired (usually lighter) material and/or [object property](/wiki/Object_property "Object property") makes them much more attractive propositions for most EvilHack characters compared to vanilla *NetHack*.

### Hack'EM

[Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM") adds Bradamante's Fury from SpliceHack, improving the damage bonus to +1d12 and changing its alignment to lawful to match the source material. Forging recipes are the same as in EvilHack.

## Encyclopedia entry

With this the wind increased, and the mill sails began to turn  
about; which Don Quixote espying, said, 'Although thou movest  
more arms than the giant Briareus thou shalt stoop to me.'  
And, after saying this, and commending himself most devoutly  
to his Lady Dulcinea, desiring her to succor him in that trance,  
covering himself well with his buckler, and setting his lance  
on his rest, he spurred on Rozinante, and encountered with the  
first mill that was before him, and, striking his lance into  
the sail, the wind swung it about with such fury, that it broke  
his lance into shivers, carrying him and his horse after it,  
and finally tumbled him a good way off from it on the field in  
evil plight.

\[ Don Quixote of La Mancha by Miquel de  
           Cervantes Saavedra ]

rawPage: {{languages}} {{weapon |color=metal color |tile=[[image:lance.png]] |name=lance |smalldmg=1d6 |largedmg=1d8 |cost=10 |weight=180 |material=iron }} A '''lance''' is a type of [[weapon]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is a one-handed weapon that is designed for use in [[mount]]ed combat, and is made of [[iron]]. Lances behave similarly to [[polearm]]s, only dealing full damage when used for [[pounding]] monsters as well as mounted [[melee]] attacks. ==Generation== Lances make up about 0.4% of randomly generated weapons (on the floor, as [[death drop]]s, or in [[shop]]s). All [[Knight]]s start with a [[Enchantment|+1]] lance.{{refsrc|src/u_init.c|75|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} [[Watchmen]] and [[soldier]]s may [[Monster starting inventory|be generated with]] a lance.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|194|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/objects.c|236|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} {{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|Per {{commit|da859c5eb88e17d04ec2bb37e2c12842e9f4c4a9}}, lances no longer generate on watchmen and soldiers.}} ==Lance skill== {{lance skill table}} The lance is the only weapon to use the '''lance [[skill]]''', and there are no [[artifact]] lances. The range at which a character or monster can [[pound]] with a lance varies with skill level - see that article for more information. ==Jousting== When a mounted character attacks an adjacent monster in melee with a lance, there is a skill-dependent chance of '''jousting''' the monster:{{refsrc|src/uhitm.c|1445|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=joust function}}. the base chance is {{frac|5}}, and increases by an additional {{frac|5}} for each skill level (i.e. {{frac|2|5}} at Basic, {{frac|3|5}} at Skilled, and {{frac|4|5}} at Expert). If jousting as part of [[twoweapon]]ing, the skill level used is the lower between the character's lance skill and their twoweapon skill, e.g. the chance of jousting with an offhand lance is {{frac|5}} if the character is unskilled in two-weapon combat. A monster that is jousted monster takes +2d10 damage (or +2d2 if the lance is twoweaponed in the offhand), loses all its movement points for that turn, and becomes [[stun]]ned; the monster is also pushed back one [[square]] in the direction of the melee attack, if they are not currently immobilized (e.g. they are trapped, as opposed to being [[sessile]]) and are of medium [[size]] or smaller, and the target square is not occupied or deadly. Each joust also has a [[luck]]-based chance of breaking the lance (with a hypothetical artifact lance resisting this chance completely), unless the jousting occurs against an [[unsolid]] monster:{{refsrc|src/uhitm.c|1466|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=odds of lance breaking}} {|class="prettytable" !Luck !Break chance |- | −13 |1 in 18 |- | −5 |1 in 43 |- | −1 |1 in 126 |- | 0 |1 in 250 |- | +1 |1 in 9550 |- | +5 |1 in 10500 |- | +13 |1 in 12500 |} ==Strategy== The lance is an extremely heavy weapon that is only second in [[weight]] to the [[heavy iron ball]], and as its base damage is quite low for that weight, a character seeking a weapon solely for pounding will prefer any polearm - the lance's primary perks lie in its jousting ability, which more than makes up for the lance's base damage and turns it into one of the most powerful non-artifact weapons. Jousts can push monsters into pounding range, and with sufficient player skill it is possible to stay a knight's jump away from monsters with ranged attacks and pound at them without fear of retaliation. Lances are difficult to come by, meaning that most players only attempt this with Knights and their starting lance once they secure enough positive luck - until then, a lance is most safely applied at range, ideally with a backup weapon and/or space to retreat when opponents close in; even low-skill Knights in an open space can make particularly good use of this strategy with their role's [[jumping]] ability. [[Barracks]] offer the best odds of finding a backup lance, particularly in the [[Castle]] and [[Fort Ludios]], and dedicated lancers can [[wish]] up a spare or backup if all else fails - a [[light source]] is also worth carrying around to keep the character's pounding range illuminated. A deadly jousting tactic at high skill level is to pound at a monster that comes in range until it moves adjacent to the character, then melee with the lance to push it back into pounding range: this potentially stunlocks monsters to death without them getting a chance to attack, and with enough movement speed even covetous monsters like many of the [[demon lords and princes]] are unlikely to get a single turn in. {{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|The removal of lances from watchmen and soldier starting inventories means that lances will be much more difficult to come by through regular means for most characters.}} ==History== The lance first appears in [[NetHack 1.3d]]. ==Origin== {{wikipedia|Lance}} A lance is a long thrusting spear designed to be used by a mounted warrior or cavalry soldier (called a lancer). In ancient and medieval warfare, it evolved into the leading weapon in cavalry charges, and was unsuited for throwing or for repeated thrusting unlike similar weapons typically used by infantry. Lances were often equipped with a vamplate, a small circular plate to prevent the hand sliding up the shaft upon impact; beginning in the late 14th century, they were used in conjunction with a lance rest attached to the breastplate. Though best known as a military and sporting weapon carried by European knights and men-at-arms, the use of lances was widespread throughout Eastern Asia, the Middle East, and Northern Africa wherever suitable mounts were available. Lancers of the medieval period also carried secondary weapons such as swords, battle axes, war hammers, maces and daggers for use in hand-to-hand combat, since the lance was often a one-use-per-engagement weapon; assuming the lance survived the initial impact without breaking, it was often too long, heavy, and/or slow to be effective in a melee. ==Variants== Some variants add artifact lances, which will not break when jousting as explained above. ===SLASH'EM=== In [[SLASH'EM]], the range of pounding is also unrestricted, and lances can hit any square that is two squares away from the wielder. Two of the five roles that are new to SLASH'EM can raise their skill in lances: {| class="prettytable" ! colspan="2" style="font-size:larger" | Polearms |- ! Max !! Role |- | Basic | * [[Ice Mage]] |- | Skilled | * [[Yeoman]] |} ===SporkHack=== [[SporkHack]] changes the additional jousting damage from 2d10 to 2d(5 + {{frac|XL|3}}). ===dNetHack=== In [[dNetHack]] and [[notdNetHack]], the lance's weight is reduced to 80 aum, and both variants add the [[elven lance]], [[droven lance]], [[white vibrospear]], [[gold-bladed vibrospear]], and [[force pike]] as weapons that use the lance skill. [[Berith]] is a [[Spirits (dNetHack)|spirit]] that grants skill in lances while bound. [[Iron golem]]s may be generated with a lance. There are several artifact lances: * [[dNetHack artifacts#Dragonlance|Dragonlance]] is an unaligned artifact that is made of [[dragontooth]]. It has +1d10 [[to-hit]] and deals +1d20 bonus damage against dragons and reptilians, with a {{frac|10}} chance of [[canceling]] those monsters on hit, subject to their [[Magic resistance (monster)|MR score]]. While wielded, Dragonlance confers [[Warned of monster type|warning of dragons and reptilians]], and grants vanilla-strength [[reflection]]. * [[dNetHack artifacts#Rhongomyniad|Rhongomyniad]] is a lawful artifact that favors Knights and is the first [[sacrifice gift]] for Knights. It has +1d3 to-hit and double damage versus all monsters, and if gifted to a character, it unrestricts the riding, [[martial arts]] and lance skills and comes with a [[saddle]]. * [[dNetHack artifacts#Lance of Uriel|The Lance of Uriel]] is a lawful intelligent artifact that is large and made of [[silver]]. It has +1d7 to-hit and +1d10 damage versus all monsters, and while wielded it grants [[automatic searching]] and [[blindness resistance]], and acts as a [[light source]]; targets that it strikes may be [[blind]]ed, [[gremlin]]s are reduced to dust, and [[Troll (monster class)|trolls]] are [[petrified]]. * [[The Rod of Lordly Might]], [[dNetHack artifacts#The Rod of the Elvish Lords|The Rod of the Elvish Lords]] and [[dNetHack artifacts#The Sceptre of Lolth|The Sceptre of Lolth]] can be [[invoke]]d to take on the form of an appropriate lance. ===FIQHack=== In [[FIQHack]], [[Dragonbane]] has its [[base item]] changed from a [[broadsword]] to a lance. Dragonbane is the first sacrifice gift for Knights, and deals +1d20 against [[dragon]]s - it also confers reflection while wielded, as in ''NetHack''. Dragonbane has half the weight of a regular lance at 90 aum, and being gifted Dragonbane unrestricts riding and provides a free saddle. ===SpliceHack=== In [[SpliceHack]], [[Bradamante's Fury]] is a neutral artifact lance that has +1d5 to-hit and +1d10 damage bonuses versus all monsters. It has a {{frac|10}} chance of stunning a monster on each hit, and instantly dismounts any mounted monsters it hits and stuns them. ===EvilHack=== In [[EvilHack]], a lance can be created at a [[Forge (dungeon feature)|forge]] by combining a [[glaive]] and a [[javelin]]. The ability to forge lances of a desired (usually lighter) material and/or [[object property]] makes them much more attractive propositions for most EvilHack characters compared to vanilla ''NetHack''. ===Hack'EM=== [[Hack'EM]] adds Bradamante's Fury from SpliceHack, improving the damage bonus to +1d12 and changing its alignment to lawful to match the source material. Forging recipes are the same as in EvilHack. ==Encyclopedia entry== {{encyclopedia| With this the wind increased, and the mill sails began to turn about; which Don Quixote espying, said, 'Although thou movest more arms than the giant Briareus thou shalt stoop to me.' And, after saying this, and commending himself most devoutly to his Lady Dulcinea, desiring her to succor him in that trance, covering himself well with his buckler, and setting his lance on his rest, he spurred on Rozinante, and encountered with the first mill that was before him, and, striking his lance into the sail, the wind swung it about with such fury, that it broke his lance into shivers, carrying him and his horse after it, and finally tumbled him a good way off from it on the field in evil plight. |[ Don Quixote of La Mancha by Miquel de Cervantes Saavedra ] }} ==References== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Weapons]] [[Category:Skills]]
